questions.question:
Question 1: A 26-year-old woman presents with 2 months of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. On 
ultrasound examination, all of the following are assessed except  
.
questions.explanation:
Amniotic fluid volume is assessed on ultrasound in the second and third trimesters. Ultrasonographic evaluation during the first trimester includes: • Gestational sac size, location, and number • Embryo and/or yolk sac identification • Crown-rump length 165 
Sold by @itachibot • Fetal number, including amnionicity and chorionicity of multifetal gestations • Embryonic/fetal cardiac activity • Maternal uterus, adnexa, and cul-de-sac • Fetal nuchal translucency.

questions.question:
Question 2: A primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic for the first time at 18 weeks of amenorrhea. 
She does not remember her LMP and no ultrasound scans were done in the first trimester. In 
this situation, gestational age can be most accurately estimated by which of the following 
parameters?
questions.explanation:
In the second trimester, the parameter to assess gestational age most accurately is the biparietal 
diameter (BPD). Accuracy varies from 7 to 10 days. BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum 
pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner 
edge of the skull in the far field. Parameter Trimes 
ter First 
Crown rump length (CRL) Second 
Biparietal diameter (BPD) Third 
Femur length (FL)

questions.question:
Question 3: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive 
UPT. Her ultrasound scan is shown below. What does the red arrowhead represent? 159 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The yellow arrowhead shows the double ring - outer 
decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis. It is referred to as the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal 
sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy. 166 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Head circumference is measured from which of the following ultrasonographic views?
questions.explanation:
Head circumference (HC) is measured from the transthalamic view by placing an ellipse around 
the outer edge of the skull HC can also be calculated from the biparietal diameter (BPD) and occipital-frontal diameter 
(OFD).

questions.question: Question 5: What is the normal range of femur length to abdominal circumference ratio?
questions.explanation:
The normal range for the femoral length (FL) to abdominal circumference (AC) ratio is 20-24 
percent. Low FL/AC (< 16) ratio suggests a lethal skeletal dysplasia, particularly if other skeletal 
abnormalities are present.

questions.question:
Question 6: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows 
the following finding. What is the next step of management?

options.c: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing 
below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has 
exceeded 32 weeks, the pregnancy can be terminated. In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but don't appear 
below it. This suggests a fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if 
>34 weeks. 167 
Sold by @itachibot Reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) suggests impending fetal death, hence the pregnancy is 
terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is true regarding the first-trimester ultrasound?

options.a: A gestational sac can first be seen 4 weeks after LMP
options.b: Accuracy of USG dating decreases after the 1st trimester
options.c: Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
options.d: A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.explanation:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester 
and decreases afterwards. Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal 
sonography(TVS). Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of 
the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy. Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a 
pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done 
between 11-14 weeks. It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and 
soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is 
increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is 
significantly elevated. First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic 
measurement: • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) 168 
Sold by @itachibot • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) • Nuchal translucency (NT) It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the 
first-trimester serum-free -hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 
and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower. Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second 
trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following are sonographic markers for Down's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound markers for Down's syndrome: • First trimester • Nuchal translucency >3 mm • Second trimester • Echogenic intracardiac focus • Ventriculomegaly • Nuchal thickness >6 mm • Echogenic bowel • Hypoplastic/absent nasal bone • Shortened humerus, femur • Mild pylectasis • Aberrant subclavian artery. 169 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: The anomaly scan of a G3A2 woman is given below. Identify the sign.
questions.explanation:
The given image shows banana sign. An abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces 
this appearance. It is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation. Lemon sign: Axial USG image of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows 
inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head 
the appearance of a lemon. It has a strong association with spina bifida and is very useful for 
detecting this condition.

questions.question:
Question 11: 162 
Sold by @itachibot A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a 
developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following USG finding 
is seen. Identify the defect.
questions.explanation:
170 
Sold by @itachibot The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin leading to the exposure 
of the cranial neural tube. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly. Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable 
congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also 
be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the 
radiological signs seen in anencephaly. • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a 
frog. • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized 
mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial 
appearance. Neural-tube defects can be prevented with pre-conceptional supplementation of folic acid. A dose 
of 4 mg daily is recommended in subsequent pregnancies. The frog eye and showercap signs are shown below: 171 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid 
abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a 
sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix). Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left 
posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing 
lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. The images below 
show the MRI and USG appearance of cystic hygroma, respectively: 172 
Sold by @itachibot Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural 
tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. The image shows a newborn with encephalocele.

questions.question: Question 12: What is Robert's sign?
questions.explanation:
Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the fetal heart. It is seen in fetal demise in utero and may appear 
as early as 12 hours. Other sonographic signs seen in fetal demise in utero are: • Absent fetal heartbeat • Absent fetal movements 173 
Sold by @itachibot • Occasional findings • Overlapping of skull bones - Spalding's sign • Gross distortion of fetal anatomy (maceration) • Soft tissue edema - skin >5 mm • Echogenic amniotic fluid (fetal demise fragments) • Uncommon findings • Thrombus in fetal heart • Gas shadow in the fetal heart - Robert's sign.

questions.question: Question 13: What is the frequency of a transabdominal transducer?
questions.explanation:
The frequency of trans abdominal transducer is 4-6 megahertz (MHz) since a lower frequency 
penetrates better. On the other hand, a vaginal transducer has a frequency of 5-10 megahertz since a higher 
frequency yields a better image with minimal penetration.

questions.question: Question 14: When is fetal cardiac activity first detected on transabdominal USG?
questions.explanation:
The cardiac activity of the fetus is first detected on transabdominal USG (TAS) at the 6th week of 
intrauterine life. Fetal structure

eks) TAS(we 
eks) Gestational sac 
4.5 
5.5 Yolk sac

6 - 7 Cardiac activit

questions.question:
Question 15: A pregnant woman has her first antenatal visit in the 8th month of gestation. On 
examination, the uterus corresponds to 30 weeks and the fetal heart rate is 136/min. What is 
the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Femur length is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in the 3rd trimester. Best USG parameters for estimation of fetal age: Parameter Trimes 
ter First 
Crown-rump length (CR 
L) 174 
Sold by @itachibot Parameter Trimes 
ter Second 
Biparietal diameter (BPD) Third 
Femur length (FL)

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is false regarding sonography in pregnancy?

options.b: All machines must display thermal index
options.c: Tissue heating is higher with shorter examination time
options.d: Risks are greater during organogenesis than later in pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Tissue heating is higher with longer examination time. Sonography should be performed in compliance with the ALARA principle which is As Low As 
Reasonably Achievable. The theoretical risks are greater during organogenesis (8-15 weeks) than 
later in pregnancy. All sonography machines must display 2 indices - the thermal index and the mechanical index.

questions.question:
Question 17: A pregnant diabetic woman presents for a routine antenatal visit during the third trimester. 
During the evaluation, you perform obstetrical Doppler imaging. Which among the following 
would indicate fetal compromise?
questions.explanation:
Absent end diastolic flow indicates fetal compromise in Doppler. Umbilical artery vessels: • They are characterized by forward low-resistance flow. • As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices so the amount of 
forward diastolic flow increases. • S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases. Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery: • Reduced end-diastolic flow - Uteroplacental insufficiency (systolic/diastolic ratio increases) • Absent end-diastolic flow - Fetal compromise (hence pregnancy is terminated by cesarean 
section if >34 weeks) • Reverse end-diastolic flow - Impending death (pregnancy is terminated irrespective of 
gestational age) Doppler of the middle cerebral artery helps in detecting fetal anemia. Increased fetal diastolic flow 
in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta implies fetal acidemia. 175 
Sold by @itachibot 176 
Sold by @itachibot Normal Labour
